description: From Middle English tawen, from Old English tawian (‚Äúto do, make‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *taw≈çn, a variant of Proto-West Germanic *tauwjan, from Proto-Germanic *tawjanƒÖ (‚Äúto make, prepare‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *dewh‚ÇÇ- (‚Äúto tie to, secure‚Äù).

Cognate with Dutch touwen (‚Äúto rope, tether, curry‚Äù), Dutch tuien (‚Äúto fasten with ropes‚Äù), German Tau (‚Äúrope, hawser, cable‚Äù), Gothic êçÑêå∞êåøêåæêå∞êåΩ (taujan, ‚Äúto make, prepare‚Äù). Related to tool and tether.

verbs.description: taw (third-person singular simple present taws, present participle tawing, simple past and past participle tawed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To prepare or dress, as hemp, by beating; to tew.
(transitive, by extension) To beat; to scourge.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To dress and prepare, as the skins of sheep, lambs, goats, and kids, for gloves, etc., by imbuing them with alum, salt, and other agents, for softening and bleaching them.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To turn (animals' hide) into leather, usually by soaking it in a certain solution.
A favorite marble in the game of marbles.
A line or mark from which the players begin a game of marbles.

examples: Walk around your corner; see-saw around your taw.

entries.meaning: A favorite person; beloved, partner, spouse.

verbs.description: taw (third-person singular simple present taws, present participle tawing, simple past and past participle tawed)

entries.meaning: The 22nd and last letter of many Semitic alphabets/abjads, including Phoenician, Aramaic, Hebrew, Syriac, and Arabic.

verbs.description: taw (third-person singular simple present taws, present participle tawing, simple past and past participle tawed)

entries.meaning: To push; to tug; to tow.
